text.content:
Ainsworth, M. D. S., & Bell, S. M. (1970). Attachment, exploration, and separation: Illustrated by the behavior of one-year-olds in a strange situation. Child Development, 41, 49–67.

Ainsworth, M. D. S., Blehar, M. C., Waters, E., & Wall, S. (1978). Patterns of attachment: A psychological study of the Strange Situation. Hillsdale, NJ: Erlbaum.

American Academy of Child Adolescent Psychiatry. (2008). Discipline. Facts for Families, 43. Retrieved from http://www.aacap.org/cs/root/facts_for_families/discipline

Ashiabi, G. S. (2000). Promoting the emotional development of preschoolers. Early Childhood Education Journal, 28(2), 79–84.

Berlin, L., Ispa, J., Fine, M., Malone, P., Brooks-Gunn, J., Brady-Smith, C., et. al. (2009). Correlates and consequences of spanking and verbal punishment for low-income White, African American, and Mexican American toddlers. Child Development, 80(5), 1403–1420.

Bowlby, J. (1969). Attachment and loss: Volume 1. Attachment. New York, NY: Basic Books.

Brazelton, T. B. & Sparrow, J. D. (2001) Touchpoints three to six: Your child's emotional and behavioral development. Cambridge, MA: Perseus Publishing.

Cimpian, A., Arce, H., Markman, E., & Dweck, C. (2007). Subtle linguistic cues affect children's motivation. Psychological Science, 18(4), 314–316.

Cole, P. M., Martin, S. E., & Dennis, T. A. (2004). Emotional regulation as a scientific construct: Challenges and directions for child development research. Child Development, 75, 317–333.

Denham, S.A. (1998). Emotional development in young children. New York, NY: Guilford Press.

Elias, M. & Arnold, H. (2006). The educators guide to emotional intelligence and academic achievement. Thousand Oaks, CA: Corwin Press.

Fabes, R. A. & Eisenberg, N. (1992). Young children’s coping with interpersonal anger. Child Development, 63, 116–128.

Goleman, D. (1995). Emotional intelligence. New York, NY: Bantam Books.

Goleman, D. (1998). Working with emotional intelligence. New York, NY: Bantam Books.

Gottman, J., & DeClaire, J. (1997). Raising an emotionally intelligent child: The heart of parenting. New York, NY: Fireside.

Gottman, J., Guralnick, M., Wilson, B., & Swanson, C. (1997). What should the focus of emotion regulation in children? A nonlinear dynamic mathematical model of children's peer interaction in groups. Development and Psychopathology, 9(2), 421–452.

Gottman, J., Katz, L., & Hooven, C. (1997). Meta-emotion: How families communicate emotionally. Mahwah, NJ: Lawrence Erlbaum.

Greenberg, M.T. (1999). Attachment and psychopathology in childhood. In J. Cassidy & P.R. Shaver (Eds.), Handbook of attachment: Theory, research, and clinical application (pp. 469–496). New York, NY: Guilford Press.

Greenberg, M. T., & Snell, J. L. (1997). Brain development and emotional development: The role of teaching in organizing the frontal lobe. In Peter Salovey & David J. Sluyter (Eds.). Emotional development and emotional intelligence: Educational implications. 93–126. New York, NY: Basic Books.

Henderlong, J. & Lepper, M. (2002). The effects of praise on children's intrinsic motivation: A review and synthesis. Psychological Bulletin, 128(5), 774–795.

Hirsh-Pasek, K., Golinkoff, R., Berk, L. & Singer, D. (2009). A mandate for playful learning in preschool. (In-Press). New York, NY: Oxford University Press.

Honig, A. S. (2010). Little kids, big worries: Stress and young children: Stress-busting tips for early childhood classrooms. Baltimore, MD: Paul H. Brookes Publishing.

Houck, G. & Lecuyer-Maus, E. (2004). Maternal limit setting during toddlerhood, delay of gratification, and behavior programs at age five. Infant Mental Health Journal, 25(1), 28–46.

Howes, C. & Matheson, C. C. (1992). Sequences in the development of competent play with peers: Social and social pretend play. Developmental Psychology, 28, 961–974.

Kann, R. T. & Hanna, F. J. (2000). Disruptive behavior disorders in children and adolescents. Journal of Counseling & Development, 78(4), 267–274.

Karp, H. (2004). The happiest toddler on the block. New York, NY: Bantam Books.

Koch, E. (2003). Reflections on a study of temper tantrums in older children. Psychoanalytic Psychology, 20(3), 456–471.

Kochanska, G., Coy, K. C., & Murray, K. T. (2001). The development of self-regulation in the first four years of life. Child Development, 72, 1091–1111.

Lantieri, L. (2008). Building Emotional Intelligence: Techniques for cultivating inner strength in children. Boulder, CO: Sounds True.

Lenzi, D., Trentini, C., Pantano, P., Macaluso, E., lacoboni, M., Lenzi, G. L., & Ammaniti, M. (2009). Neural basis of maternal communication and emotional expression processing during infant preverbal stage. Cerebral Cortex, 19(5), 1124–33.

Lyons-Ruth, K. (1996). Attachment relationships among children with aggressive behavior problems: The role of disorganized early attachment patterns. Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology, 64, 32–40.

Marvin, R. S., Cooper, G., Hoffman, K., & Powell, B. (2002). The Circle of Security project: Attachment-based intervention with caregiver-preschool child dyads. Attachment & Human Development, 4, 107–124.

Meyer, W. (1992). Paradoxical effects of praise and criticism on perceived ability. European review of social psychology, 3, 259–283.

Morawska, A., & Sanders, M. (2010). Parental use of time out revisited: A useful or harmful parenting strategy? Journal of Child & Family Studies, 20(1), 1–8.

Nelsen, J., Lott, L., Glenn, H. S. (1993). Positive discipline A-Z: 1001 solutions to everyday parenting problems. Rocklin, CA: Prima Publishing.

Newton, R. (2008). The attachment connection. Oakland, CA: New Harbinger Publications.

Pirak, C. & Gottman J. (2008). Emotional Communication and Children.

Saarni, C. (1990). Emotional competence. In Ross Thompson (Ed.). Nebraska Symposium: Socioemotional development (pp.115–161). Lincoln, NE: University of Nebraska Press.

Sagi, A., van IJzendoorn, M. H., & Koren-Kane, N. (1991). Primary appraisal of the Strange Situation: A cross-cultural analysis of the pre-separation episodes. Developmental Psychology, 27, 587–596.

Sroufe, L. A. (1989). Attachment Theory and the Aftermath of Divorce.

Sigler, E., Aamidor, S. (2005). From positive reinforcement to positive behaviors: An everyday guide for the practitioner. Early Childhood Education Journal, 32(4), 249–253.

Solter, A. (1992). Understanding tears and tantrums. Young Children, 47(4), 64–68.

Sroufe, L. A. (1997). Emotional development: The organization of emotional life in the early years. New York, NY: Cambridge University Press.

Stormshak, E., Bierman, K., McMahon, R., & Lengua, L. (2000). Parenting practices and child disruptive behavior problems in early elementary school. Journal of Clinical Child Psychology, 29 (1), 17–30.

Takahashi, K. (2005). Toward a life span theory of close relationships: The affective relationships model. Human Development, 48, 48–66.

Thompson, R.A. (1994). Emotion regulation: A theme in search of definition. In M.A. Fox (Ed.), The development of emotion regulation: Biological and behavioral considerations. Monographs of the Society for Research in Child Development, 59 (2-3 Serial no. 240), 25–52.

Tronick, E.Z. (1989). Emotions and emotional communication in infants. American Psychologist, 44, 112–119.

van ljzendoorn, M. H., & Kroonenberg, P. M. (1998). Cross-cultural patterns of attachment: A meta-analysis of the strange situation. Child Development, 59, 147–156.

van ljzendoorn, M. H., & Sagi, A. (1999). Cross-Cultural Patterns of Attachment: Universal and Contextual Dimensions. In J. Cassidy & P. Shaver (Eds.), Handbook of attachment theory and research (pp. 713–734). New York, NY: Guildford Press.
